newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-BHP plans US$470 mln Escondida upgrade.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-BHP plans US$470 mln Escondida upgrade.

text.p: The Broken Hill Pty Co Ltd said on Friday it planned to spend US$470 million on the Escondida Oxide project at its copper mine in northern Chile.

BHP said the Escondida Oxide project would proceed subject to approval of the Chilean government environmental review agency, the COREMA. It said all of the Escondida owners had now approved the project subject to COREMA approval.
It said the investment would provide 270 new permanent jobs and a construction employment peak of 3,000.
"The synergies between the oxide project and the large existing Escondida sulpghide operation would enhance the overall economics considerably," it said.
Project construction was expected to take 18 to 20 months, it said.
BHP said the COREMA approval was expected by the end of March 1997. If this date was realised, the initial cathode production would begin in September 1998.
It said the Escondida oxide project involved acid leaching of oxide mineral crushed and stacked in heaps.

The resultant copper rich soluctions contained within the impermeable liners at the base of the heaps, were then passed through solvent extraction upgrading and finally an electrowinning process to produce copper cathodes, it said.
Annual production would be 125,000 tonnes of copper metal, it said.
BHP owns 57.5 percent of Escondida, RTZ-CRA group owns 30 percent, JECO holds 10 percent and International Finance Corp 2.5 percent.
